dataIdInfo.idPurp:
These estuarine watershed boundaries are intended to provide a basis for an estuary assessment and delineation that will allow for MBP to periodically assess the health of estuarine systems within its planning area. The watersheds assessment will aid in development of the MBP Comprehensive Conservation and Management Plan (CCMP). This plan will focus on management strategies for nearshore communities to improve water quality, protect habitat, and increase habitat continuity.
These estuarine watershed boundaries are an update of a previous set used for estuarine assessment in 2012. This update increases the number of estuarine assessment areas from 47 to 69 and includes new interestuarine/shoreline drainage areas that were not previously assessed.
dataIdInfo.idAbs: These polygons depict the boundaries of 69 near-shore estuarine and interestuarine watersheds within the Massachusetts Bays Program management area. These watersheds are located along the eastern Massachusetts coast from the Merrimack River in the north to Provincetown Harbor at the tip of Cape Cod. They are intended to encompass all tributary areas that are tidally influenced, as well as open water regions within the estuaries and other offshore areas that contain important ecological resources.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Name of estuary or estuary complex (EDA1)
Name of estuary, estuary complex, or inter-estuarine area (EDA2)
Area of feature in internal units squared.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

descript.abstract: These polygons depict the boundaries of 69 near-shore estuarine and inter-estuarine watersheds within the Massachusetts Bays Program management area. These estuaries are located along the eastern Massachusetts coast from the Merrimack River in the north to Provincetown Harbor at the tip of Cape Cod. They are intended to encompass all tributary areas that are tidally influenced, as well as open water regions of the estuaries that contain important ecological resources.
descript.purpose:
These estuarine watershed boundaries are intended to provide a basis for an estuary assessment and delineation that will lay the groundwork for MBP to periodically assess the health of estuarine systems within its planning area. The watersheds assessment will aid in development of the MBP Comprehensive Conservation and Management Plan (CCMP). This plan will focus on management strategies for nearshore communities to improve water quality, protect habitat, and increase habitat continuity.
This dataset is an update to a previous assessment unit delineation in 2012. It increases the number of assessment watersheds from 47 to 69 and includes inter-estuarine and shoreline drainage areas that were not previously assessed.
descript.supplinf: A more detailed discussion of delineation methods and a full listing of all the sources used is presented in the report, "MassBays Estuarine Assessment and Delineation 2.0," March 2017.

idinfo.useconst: The data were developed by Geosyntec Consultants, Inc. for the Massachussets Bays Program and are intended for planning purposes.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows 7 Enterprise Service Pack 1; ESRI ArcCatalog 10.0 (Build 2414)

citeinfo.title: Report: "MassBays Estuarine Assessment and Delineation 2.0," March 2017.

distinfo.distliab: No warranty is expressed or implied by Geosyntec Consultants regarding the accuracy of the data. Any use of trade, product, or firm names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by Geosyntec. This layer is intended for planning purposes only.
distinfo.techpreq: This data may be used in many standard GIS software products. See each software's vendor for technical prerequisites.

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata

dataqual.complete: The estuarine watershed boundaries intended to cover the entire coastline within the Massachusetts Bays Program management area. They depict near shore tributary areas and open water regions of those specific estuaries identified by MBP and its regional coordinators for inclusion within the estuary assessment and delineation, as well as inter-estuarine/shoreline drainage areas that drain directly to the ocean rather than some estuarine waterbody. The watersheds also only encompass tributary areas that are directly proximal to the estuary or shoreline and/or tidally influenced. They may omit tributary areas such as major freshwater rives and lakes that extend inland and are not estuarine or coastal in nature. Determnation of these distinctions is discussed further in the "MassBays Estuarine Assessment and Delineation 2.0," March 2017.
dataqual.logic: The dataset was reviewed by Geosyntec for agreement with the various topographic data used to determine the watershed delineations. The delineations were reviewed by MBP for consistency with previous delineations, resource locations, and regional coordinators' knowledge of the contributing areas.

procstep.procdesc:
Seaward estuarine boundaries were determined using using the Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection (MassDEP) 2010 Integrated List of Waters, or the 305(b) list, which provides boundaries of estuary segments. Additionally the seaward boundary was extended to the 10m bathymetric contour on the basis of including the photic zone within the open water areas of the estuarine assessment unit boundary. The seaward boundaries were then expanded to include any nearby estuarine resources, including tidal flats, seagrass beds, and shellfish habitat.
Landward boundaries were determined for any estuary with major freshwater tributaries. Chapter 91 Tidelands Jurisdictional mapping as well as MA state maps of saltwater wetlands were used to interpret the extent of tidal influence along these freshwater tributaries.
Hydrologic basins on Cape Cod are dominated by groundwater flow and cannot be delineated using surface topography. The primary source of estuarine groundwater contributing areas (GWCA) on Cape Cod is data layer created by USGS in cooperation with USEPA. This data layer contains groundwater contributing areas generated using regional MODFLOW groundwater models of the Cape Cod aquifer system. In some cases, the seaward estuarine boundary was further modified to better tie into these existing basin boundaries. Additional reports by the Massachusetts Estuaries Project and USGS were used to supplement the GWCA boundaries.
A more detailed discussion of delineation methods and a full listing of all the sources used is presented in the report, "MassBays Estuarine Assessment and Delineation 2.0," March 2017.
